source.author: Duretto, M.F.
source.title: Rutaceae
source.in_title: Flora of Victoria. Vol. 4. Cornaceae to Asteraceae

leads.lead_text: Petals free at or immediately after anthesis
Petals remaining fused into a tube
Petals pale green to bluish, 15–30 mm long; flowers distinctly stalked, pedicel 1–3 cm long; non-coastal, western Victoria
Petals white (rarely pink), less than 15 mm long; flowers subsessile or pedicels to 5 mm long; coastal
Adaxial surface of leaves pubescent or slightly scabrous
Adaxial surface of leaves smooth and glabrous or nearly so
Staminal filaments linear throughout; corolla pink to red, cream, yellow or green; usually tall shrubs of tall wet forests or gullies

Staminal filaments, at least the antepetalous ones, widened at base; corolla usually cream, green or yellow, but sometimes red or dull pink; usually low shrubs (rarely to 2 m high) of heathlands, woodlands and usually drier open-forest, or garden-escaped plants
Calyx and lower surfaces of leaves with a dense tomentum; corolla cream or red
Calyx and leaves glabrous or glabrescent; corolla pale green to pale yellow or pink
Leaves broadly elliptic to ovate, margin entire, flat; Cape Otway area only
Leaves narrow oblong to cordate, margin entire to crenulate, flat to recurved; widespread
Calyx and pedicel almost or quite glabrous; corolla pink
Calyx and pedicel variably hairy; corolla pale green to pale yellow
